A New York woman who has waited decades to publicly accuse a Catholic priest of rape kicked off more than 100 lawsuits filed in the wake of a new state law which has opened a one-year window for sexual abuse survivors to come forward. The Child Victims Act removes the statue of limitations to allow victims in New York to pursue legal action no matter the age of the accuser, when the abuse occurred or if the alleged perpetrator is alive or dead. It also allows criminal charges to be filed until accusers turn 28‚Äìup from age 23. One woman, called Jane Doe in her suit, had filed against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. The latest casualty of Trump's demands for a border wall may be La Lomita Chapel, a small Catholic church built in 1899 in Mission, TX. Today, the chapel serves as a tourist attraction because of its rich history as a site where Calvary of Christ missionaries performed baptisms, marriages, and funerals. In a number of tiny Texan border towns, Trump's administration has filed court notices demanding "immediate possession" of privately owned land for possible sites to construct fencing, and barriers. "They are trying to bully us, but we are not backing down," says Father Roy Snipes, a Catholic clergyman of a nearby church who, four decades ago, made his final vows at La Lomita. "The wall goes against our beliefs as Catholics and as Texans. We refuse to let them bulldoze our church for something that will harm people in need." Read more about the church's fight at our link in bio.

Five years ago today, then-state senator Wendy Davis (D-TX) prevented the Texas State Senate from passing anti-abortion bill SB5 after an epic 13-hour filibuster. On Sept. 8, 1957, Althea Gibson became the first African American to win the U.S. Open. The same year in July, she became the first POC to win at Wimbledon. She received her trophy personally from Queen Elizabeth II and later said, "Shaking hands with the queen of England was a long way from being forced to sit in the colored section of the bus." Gibson collected 11 Grand Slam titles and was the AP's Female Athlete of the Year in 1957 and 1958. She passed away in 2003. #boss #blackgirlmagic #history #onthisday (Credit: Getty)

"When President Donald Trump predicted Thursday that there could soon be a ‚Äúmajor, major conflict‚Äù with North Korea, critics were quick to write it off as yet another needlessly provocative and un-presidential outburst from the man occupying the Oval Office.
But aides and close associates of Trump tell a very different story. They say there‚Äôs an intentional communications strategy at work, designed by the president himself: Trump knocks opponents off-balance with unexpected tweets or comments that upset the status quo, setting up the shot, then his cabinet secretaries come in as ‚Äúsweepers,‚Äù laying out the new policy in more detail, calming the situation, and landing foreign policy goals.
That‚Äôs just what Secretary of State Rex Tillerson did Friday, in remarks at the UN intended to serve as a road map out of the confrontation for the Hermit Kingdom, suggesting Pyongyang‚Äôs leader Kim Jong Un take steps to show good faith, and holding out the tantalizing reward of millions in U.S. aid for steps toward denuclearization.

"I love to see Afghan girls improve the way other girls have improved in the world," said Sima Azimi, 20, a trainer at the Shaolin Wushu club in Afghanistan. A group of Afghan girls are learning the movements of Wushu, a sport developed from kung fu, in a country where women's sports are incredibly restricted. Many of these young women regularly face harassment and abuse, and the club teaches them self-defense. Azimi hopes her students will one day compete and win medals for their country. (Reuters)

While lawmakers have been proposing‚Äîand in North Carolina‚Äôs case, passing‚Äîanti-transgender legislation, transgender people are being killed at an unprecedented rate. The year 2015 saw an all-time high in reported killings of trans people in the United States: 21 by the time of the annual Transgender Day of Remembrance in late November. And 2016 is on track to be just as violent. This year‚Äôs victims range in age from 53 to just 16. Most were black or Latina trans women, many of whom were misgendered and misnamed by local media. Dean Martin, of Sinatra's Rat Pack, would've been 99 today. In his honor, here's the recipe for his signature "Flame of Love" martin-i: 
1 dash Tio Pepe Sherry
2 oz Vodka
Orange peels
Add sherry to a cocktail glass & swirl around. Pour out excess, then flame two orange peels over the glass. Add vodka to a cocktail shaker & fill with ice. Shake & strain into the prepared glass. Flame final piece of orange peel over finished drink & use as garnish. #drinks #drinkoftheday #drinkstagram #cocktails #classic #recipe (üì∑: Mondadori Portfolio/Getty)

On May 31, 1819, poet, teacher, and journalist Walt Whitman was born. Born in Huntington, New York (on Long Island), Whitman‚Äôs early career consisted of covering New York politics and working class affairs for local newspapers, as well as writing opera reviews, working as a teacher, and dabbling in real estate. As he took notes of his encounters with people, he began phrasing his words into rhyme and meter, eventually becoming one of the most famous collections of poems, ‚ÄúLeaves of Grass.‚Äù He observed, "Bring all the art and science of the world and baffle and humble it with one spear of grass." Without a publisher interested in his book in 1855, Whitman funded the first edition of his book of verse himself. In 1865 Whitman was dismissed from his clerk job at the Department of the Interior in Washington because a colleague thought ‚ÄúLeaves of Grass‚Äù was indecent. In his lifetime, the book went through nine editions, and is now considered a classic by literati and leaders alike. Perhaps the most well-known of his poems is "O Captain! My Captain!", written after the assassination of Abraham Lincoln in 1865, made more famous by the movie "Dead Poets Society".
Photo illustration by @BrigetteSupernova for The Daily Beast #WaltWhitman #UShistory #literature #todayinhistory #onthisdayinhistory #LeavesOfGrass #thedailybeast

@thedailybeast has curated a gallery of the most memorable, death-defying crashes in Indianapolis 500 history, where the drivers lived to race another day. Tap on the link in our bio the see more. Since its inception in 1911, The Indianapolis 500 car race has been equal parts driving skill, technological marvel, and sheer luck. There have been a total of 66 people killed during this annual Hoosier race in its century-long history‚Äîover 40 drivers, and dozens of mechanics, spectators, and 1 innocent child playing in his yard nearby. And while fatal tragedies are never hoped for, the high speed, risky maneuvers and crowds of over 300,000 people have always been a dangerous, thrilling combination at the Indianapolis 500. In the race‚Äôs early years, like any other sport, safety was not the utmost concern and wreck fatalities were higher. As technology, race regulations (including less flammable fuel), and conditions have improved, deaths have decreased significantly. But, crashes are inevitable in this high stakes, high speed competition. And we marvel at those spectacular crashes when the drivers survive!
Photo ¬©AP #Indy500 #autoracing #sports #Indycar #sportshistory #thedailybeast

On May 20, 1956, the first U.S. test of the first ‚Äúair deliverable‚Äù hydrogen bomb was dropped from a B-52 bomber near Namu Island of the Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean. Released at an altitude of more than 50,000 feet, the bomb named ‚ÄúCherokee‚Äù exploded around 15,000 feet. The bomb drop was intended to gather weapon effects data for high yield air bursts, as well as demonstrate to the Soviet Union our ability to deliver H-bombs by air. So-called Operation Redwing was a series of 17 thermonuclear test detonations done from May to June, 1956. After taking control of the peaceful Marshall Islands from the Japanese in WWII, President Truman decided to conduct 66 nuclear weapons tests on the island chain from 1946 to 1958. Just before they began testing plutonium-laced hydrogen bombs‚Äîwhich have a radioactive existence of half a million years‚Äîhundreds of island native inhabitants were relocated from Bikini Atoll to Rongerik Atoll. But after bouts of starvation and other struggles to survive, some were brought back and exposed to radiation as bomb tests were conducted. The U.S. Navy brought in 242 naval ships, 156 aircraft, 25,000 radiation recording devices, and 5,400 experimental rats, goats and pigs were imported for nuclear fallout testing. And half of the world‚Äôs moving picture film stock was shipped in to document bomb drops.
Photo Department of Defense, Cherokee hydrogen bomb explosion on May 20, 1956. #war #nuclearbomb #hbomb #plutonium #BikiniAtoll #nuclearwar #thisdayinhistory #todayinhistory #worldhistory #thedailybeast

An EgyptAir plane that took off from Paris bound for Cairo late Wednesday night has vanished from radar, the airline tweeted. Flight MS 804, which had 56 passengers, including two infants, and 10 crew members aboard, appears to have been an A320. The flight was scheduled to depart Paris Charles De Gaulle Airport at 10:45 p.m. but left shortly later, at 11:09 p.m. It lost contact once inside Egyptian airspace when at an altitude of 37,000 feet, at 2:45 a.m., according to the airline's Twitter feed. Flight MS 804 was reportedly completing its fifth flight of the day when it went missing. Search teams have found wreckage in the Mediterranean Sea. Stay tuned to @thedailybeast for updates as this tragedy unfolds.

However, a state board did not find his prolific prescription writing unethical and let him go on probation. He was acquitted of the 14 charges in late 1980. May is Motorcycle Safety and Awareness Month. Here are some safety tips for both riders and vehicle drivers to keep in mind, making the roads safer for all.
For riders:
‚Ä¢Be sure safety gear is properly fitted and does not impair vision or hearing. Be sure passengers are also properly protected‚Äîincluding helmets, jackets, and footwear.
‚Ä¢Make sure you use hand signals and turn off blinkers after turns.
‚Ä¢Always operate your bike completely sober. Reaction timing and skills diminish after even one drink.
‚Ä¢Obey the rules of the road, and stay out of vehicle blind spots.
‚Ä¢Know your skill level, choose a bike fit for your body and strength, and keep your machine tuned up for optimum performance.
For vehicle drivers:
‚Ä¢Understand motorcycles often slow down by releasing the throttle or downshifting; do not rely on brake lights to signal a decrease in speed or stop.
‚Ä¢Give motorcycles as much space as cars‚Äîin both lane width and stopping distance from you.
‚Ä¢Look twice‚Äîespecially when making left turns and at intersections, where the majority of bike accidents happen.
‚Ä¢Remember motorcycle driving is far more dangerous than operating a car or truck, and bikers need to maneuver more often to avoid road hazards.
‚Ä¢Get off your phone. Don‚Äôt text while driving or even while stopped.
Photo @istockphoto #motorcycles #motorcyclesafety #rulesoftheroad #transpirtation #thedailybeast

Say hello to our new National Mammal, the American bison. Yesterday, President Obama signed a law making the grand creature a national treasure. Although sometimes referred to as a buffalo, bison are only remotely related to the true buffalo species. There are two kinds of American bison: plains bison and wood bison. Bison are strong swimmers and can reach running speeds of up to 35 mph, despite their one ton weight! In the 19th century, nearly 50 million bison were hunted for meat and hide, lowering their numbers to mere hundreds. Thanks to breeding and protection programs, there are now an estimated 150,000 bison in the US. No longer considered endangered, bison can still be hunted, farmed, and harvested as a red meat alternative.  Photo ¬©Getty Images #NationalMammal #AmericanBison #bison @BarackObama @USinterior #animals #nationaltreasure #thedailybeast

On May 9, 1960, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the sale an oral contraceptive pill (a.k.a. ‚Äúbirth control‚Äù) for the first time. The movement was made possible in great part thanks to nurse and feminist Margaret Sanger, who founded the American Birth Control League in 1921 after years of tending to women after botched, illegal abortions. In the 1950‚Äôs, as a leader for women‚Äôs reproductive rights and health, Sanger closely followed contraception research, and used the modest inheritance left by her late husband to personally fund advancements. After bringing fellow feminist philanthropist Katharine Dexter McCormick on board to fund nearly $2 million worth of research, and years or trials tests, the drug was finally ready for the market. The pill, first called Enovid, was an instant hit and had enormous consequences in freeing women to control their lives, with an easy, affordable, reliable means to prevent unwanted pregnancies and plan families.
Photo courtesy Library of Congress/New York World-Telegram and the Sun Newspaper Photograph Collection

On May 8th, 1886, John Pemberton invented the flavor syrup for Coca-Cola. A noted physician, businessman, and pharmacist, Pemberton came up with the popular elixir in his Atlanta drug lab. His original French Wine Coca grew out of his experiments to find a non-opiate painkiller alternative to morphine. He told a local paper it was ‚Äúcomposed of an extract from the leaf of Peruvian coca, the purest wine, and the Kola nut. It is the most excellent of all tonics, assisting digestion, imparting energy to the organs of respiration, and strengthening the muscular and nervous systems‚Ä¶ without fatigue." When temperance took effect, he removed the wine component, replacing it with sugary syrup, and called it Coca Cola. His drink was highly addictive due to its three main ingredients: caffeine (from the kola nut), cocaine (from the coca leaf), and sugar for flavor. His son began marketing the refreshing soda fountain drink locally for five cents a glass, and Pemberton was sure it would eventually become ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs drink.‚Äù But due to troubled finances, Pemberton sold off his shares of the company; his son sold off the final share of the patent for quick cash. John Pemberton died of stomach cancer and addicted to morphine. The owner of Coca Cola, Asa Griggs Candler, went on to market Coke into a world-dominating brand. Today, the company manufactures a non-cocaine version of the syrup and licenses the name to be sold as a soft drink in over 200 countries.
Photo public domain #CocaCola #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #softdrink #popularculture #thedailybeast

May 6, 1856 marks the date of Sigmund Freud‚Äôs birth.
As an early 20th Century psychologist and neurologist, Freud is considered the founder of psychoanalysis. He articulated and refined the concepts of the unconscious, infantile sexuality and repression, and defined the human psyche as having three parts: id, ego, and superego. Based on his theories, he formed the modern field of psychoanalysis to treat a wide variety of abnormal mental conditions. Some of his theories are highly controversial and unproven (such as dream analysis and aberrant human sexuality), but nonetheless Freud‚Äôs lexicon is embedded within the vocabulary of western society‚Äîsuch as anal (personality), libido, denial, repression, cathartic, Freudian slip, Oedipus complex, daddy issues, hysteria, fixation, and neurotic.
Photo: Sigmund Freud in London on June 6, 1938. After the Nazi Party seized Austria‚Äîand banned Freud‚Äôs work and writings‚Äîthe doctor paid a large ransom to have his passport restored and his family moved out of the country. He was allowed to take some furniture, his library, and his collection of Greek and Egyptian antiques.
Less than a year after his escape from Nazi rule, years of worsening oral cancer complications (including 30 surgeries) caused Freud to turn to a doctor-assisted morphine death. Photo ¬©AFP/Getty Images

May 5th commemorates Cinco de Mayo. Long before it was a ‚Äúdrinking holiday‚Äù, it was an historic celebration of the day an unlikely Mexican army fought back occupied French forces at the Battle of Puebla in 1862. After two civil wars that left Mexico nearly bankrupt and unable to pay foreign debts, France, Britain, and Spain sent troops to ‚Äúnegotiate‚Äù repayments. But Napolean III saw the French presence in Mexico as an opportunity to also establish the conservative Second Mexican Empire, favoring French financial interests. 
After pushing several towns and President Benito Juarez into retreat, the army of 6,500 well-equipped French soldiers surprisingly succumbed to a far inferior Mexican militia of 2,000 near Puebla. The victory was short-lived as France later sent another 30,000 troops to overtake Mexico and install Emperor Maximillian until the U.S. arrived with troops to oust the French in 1866. 
But the one small victory on May 5, 1862 serves as a ‚ÄúDavid defeating Goliath‚Äù moment in Mexican history, bringing unity and pride to the people of Mexico who fought for their sovereignty. 
Today, Cinco de Mayo is an opportunity to celebrate Mexican culture, food, and music. 
Photo: Portrait of General Ignacio Zaragoza, who lead the mighty Mexican army in the Battle of Puebla, as depicted on a 500 pesos bill, circa 1912. #cincodemayo #may5 #pesos #mexico #battleofpuebla #worldhistory #mexicanpride #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory  #thedailybeast

In ‚ÄúA New Hope,‚Äù Princess Leia‚Äôs home planet, Alderaan, is blown to smithereens by the Empire‚Äôs Death Star as she watches in horror. Real exoplanets also experience extreme destruction. A white dwarf star was caught in the act of devouring the last bits of a small planet in 2015, observed with the help of NASA‚Äôs Chandra X-ray Observatory. White dwarfs are super-dense stellar remnants about the size of Earth, but with gravity more than 10,000 times that of our sun‚Äôs surface. Tidal forces could rip a planet caught in its pull to shreds. Here, we see an artist's concept of a very young star encircled by a disk of gas and dust. While accretion disks like this one can look like the aftermath of destruction, they're actually birthplaces for new planets.

On May 4, 1970 National Guardsmen opened fire on angry and non-dispersing, but unarmed, anti-war protestors at Kent State University in Ohio, killing four students and wounding nine others. 67 rounds were fired in seconds, into a crowd of students protesting President Nixon‚Äôs earlier announcement of military operations in Cambodia. The event created an event deeper divide on American opinions of our role in the Vietnam War. Millions of students boycotted school in the following days. Images of the aftermath, distributed around the world, amplified sentiment against American military involvement in Vietnam and Cambodia, and over 100,000 people showed up in Washington DC days later to protest the Kent State and violent events at other universisites, and the Vietnam War in general.
Photo: cover of LIFE magazine, with its coverage of Kent State, May 15, 1970 issue.

On this day in 1786 Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's opera "Marriage of Figaro" premiered in Vienna, Austria. With music composed by Mozart, the comedic opera‚Äôs Italian libretto was penned by Lorenzo Da Ponte. Set in a castle in Sevilla, Spain, the story revolves around two servant lovers, Figaro and Susanna. Their marriage foils Count Almaviva, teaching him a lesson about philandering along the way. ‚ÄúMarriage of Figaro‚Äù is consistently among the top ten most performed operas around the world.

The last Friday in April is Arbor Day. This day is about more than just tree hugging!
Founded by famous Journalist and Editor J. Sterling Morton, he sang the praises of trees and encouraged planting them in his prairie state of Nebraska. On the first Arbor Day in 1872, Morton hosted a competition in which an estimated 1 million trees were planted throughout the state! Early Arbor Day celebrations were full of fanfare and adopted most enthusiastically by school kids. It is also an opportunity to develop classroom lessons around the importance of trees and the role they play in our environment, well being, and culture. While Arbor Day is officially the last Friday in April, many states adjust their observance to best align with ideal tree planting weather‚Äînorthern states sometimes later, southern states as early as February or March.
Here are a few ways to celebrate Arbor Day:
‚Ä¢Plant trees!
‚Ä¢Choose a public park to clean up
‚Ä¢Read books with your kids about trees‚Äîbonus points if they‚Äôre digital
‚Ä¢Do a tree identification hike
‚Ä¢Share and tag your friends on this and other social media about Arbor Day
Photo ¬©istockphoto #ArborDay #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #trees #nature #thedailybeast

On April 26, 1986, the world‚Äôs worst nuclear power plant accident occurs at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Soviet Union. Dozens of people died immediately, many suffered radiation burns, and ultimately upwards of 5,000 have died as a result of the disaster. It was not until Swedish authorities 800 miles away detected strong radioactivity and reported the nuclear fallout, that the Soviets admitted to the disaster. Plant engineers with little knowledge of nuclear physics want to run an experiment on the plant‚Äôs emergency water pump system. Through a series of errors that included shutting down proper cooling system and causing an explosion, radioactive material leaked into the atmosphere. The plant was officially shut down in 2000, but not before millions of acres of land, forest, homes, and lives were damaged.
Photo: A Greenpeace activist carries several of 3,000 wooden crosses to be set up in front of the Soviet-built nuclear power plant in Bohunice, April 25, 1991 to commemorate the nuclear disaster in Chernobyl five years earlier. ¬©Thomas Szlukovenyi/Reuters

On April 24, 1800, the Library of Congress was founded. President John Adams approved $5,000 to purchase books deemed important to and for use by the Congress. The first collection contained 964 volumes (mostly law and parliamentary history) and 9 maps. On August 24, 1814, the British army invaded the White House, at all the food that had been laid out for a formal affair and looted the home, then set fire to the White House, Capitol‚Äîwhere 3,000 library books were housed‚Äîand other government buildings. One year later, Thomas Jefferson sold his nearly 7,000 books to the Library of Congress for $23,950. In 1851, another fire ravaged the Library, destroying approximately two-thirds of the collection, most of which were swiftly replaced through legislative funding. Today, the Library of Congress is the largest in the world, with over 17 million maps, manuscripts, photographs, films, artworks, audio and video recordings, prints, drawings, and ephemera.

On April 16, 1943 Swiss chemist Albert Hoffman accidentally consumed LSD-25, a drug he had created for a 1938 study on the medicinal value of lysergic acid compounds. During the purification of the condensation products, he absorbed an amount equal to a few grains of salt. Dr. Hoffman obviously took note of the unusual hallucinations and sensations he experienced after ‚Äúdropping‚Äù LSD. He observed:
‚ÄúI perceived an uninterrupted stream of fantastic pictures, extraordinary shapes with intense, kaleidoscopic play of colors. After some two hours this condition faded away.‚Äù He later consumed the compound one more time to confirm his experience was caused by the LSD-25.
Failing to find any medicinal use for the compound, Sandoz Pharmaceuticals freely gave away samples of the drug, leading to its widespread recreational use.
In the 1950‚Äôs, the US military experimented with the drug, noting it ‚Äúis capable of rendering whole groups of people, including military forces, indifferent to their surroundings and situations, interfering with planning and judgment, and even creating apprehension, uncontrollable confusion and terror.‚Äù
In the early 1950‚Äôs LSD was studied as a therapeutic substance for schizophrenia, religious psychology, depression, and PTSD. After abuse of the substance lead to negative psychological reactions in some users, the US government outlawed the drug in 1965.
Photo: poster for ‚ÄúFear and Loathing in Las Vegas‚Äù, 1998, based on the book by Hunter S. Thompson in which he famously described acid trips.
#todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #acid #lsd #lsd25 #AlbertHoffman #HunterSThompson #FearAndLoathing #drugs #thedailybeast

Today is National Donate Life Day. 
Currently, ther are 124,000 men, women and children are awaiting organ transplants in the United States.
Anyone can be a potential donor regardless of age, race, or medical history.
All major religions in the United States support organ, eye and tissue donation and see it as the final act of love and generosity toward others.
A deceased donor, who can give kidneys, pancreas, liver, lungs, heart, intestinal organs, corneas, and tissues of the skin, bones, ligaments, and heart valves.
A living donor can give a kidney, a portion of the liver, lung, intestine, or pancreas to those in need.
Spread the word, sign up to donate, fundraise, share your stories of life and health donation!

On April 13, 1999 Jack Kevorkian was sentenced to 10 - 25 years in prison for the second-degree murder of a man in the final stages of Lou Gehrig‚Äôs disease whose assisted death was videotaped and shown on the television news show "60 Minutes." Kevorkian was an American licensed pathologist and human euthanasia activist. He is best known for publicly championing a terminal patient's right to die via physician-assisted suicide. Dr. Kevorkian is credited with revolutionizing the debate on right to die patients. Since his death in 2011, Washington, Oregon, California, Vermont, and parts of New Mexico now have laws condoning physician aided dying.

On April 10, 1866, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) was founded by Henry Bergh. After seeing the brutal treatment of horses and other animals at the hands of their owners and inspired by a British animal protection agency, the New York City philanthropist and diplomat pleaded ‚ÄúThis is a matter purely of conscience; it has no perplexing side issues. It is a moral question in all its aspects.‚Äù After several dignitaries and New York leaders signed his declaration, the ASPCA was chartered and given the right to investigate and arrest acts of animal cruelty. Bergh frequently monitored slaughterhouses, shut down dog and rat fighting rings in the city, and lectured on animal anti-cruelty. His rescues of animals set precedent and served as role model for other states animal programs and the NY Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
Photo ¬©istock @ASPCA #aspca #animals #pets #livestock #animalcruelty #animalabuse #history #UShistory #thisdayinhistory #todayinhistory #thedailybeast

On April 9, 1959, NASA's first administrator, Dr. Keith Glennan, announced the names of the agency's first group of astronauts at a news conference in Washington, D.C. Now known as the "Original Seven," they included three Naval aviators, M. Scott Carpenter, Walter M. Schirra Jr., and Alan B. Shepard Jr.; three Air Force pilots, L. Gordon Cooper Jr., Virgil I. (Gus) Grissom, and Donald K. (Deke) Slayton; along with Marine Corps aviator John H. Glenn Jr. This group photo of the original Mercury astronauts was taken in June 1963 at the Manned Spacecraft Center (MSC), now Johnson Space Center, in Houston, Texas. The astronauts are, left-to-right: Cooper, Schirra, Shepard, Grissom, Glenn, Slayton and Carpenter.

Project Mercury became NASA's first major undertaking. The objectives of the program were to place a human-rated spacecraft into orbit around Earth, observe the astronaut's performance in such conditions and safely recover the astronaut and the spacecraft. The Mercury flights proved that humans could live and work in space, and paved the way for the Gemini and Apollo programs as well as for all further human spaceflight.

Text and photo courtesy NASA #nasa #space #astronaut #original7 #spacetravel #science #technology #innovation #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #thedailybeast

Namaste. Buddhists celebrate the birth of Gautama Buddha, born on this day in in 563 BC. While his actual birthdate has been debated, the day of traditions remains April 8th. The earliest known readings and teaching of Buddha state he was born a prince, destined to be a royal leader or a teacher. After living a sheltered life of riches, Prince Siddhartha left his Indian palace at age 29 to explore the world, and attempted to understand how a priest he encountered could be so content in a world of suffering. After years of wandering and pondering, the prince paused to meditate and awoke enlightened. He subsequently went on to share his teachings of the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path to followers, thus laying the foundation for Buddhism, including its five precepts:
Respect for life 
Respect for others' property  Respect for our pure and chaste nature 
Respect for honesty

On this day in 1968, the movie ‚Äú2001: A Space Odyssey‚Äù debuted in theaters. Just after 6 p.m. on April 4, 1968, Martin Luther King Jr. was fatally shot while standing on the balcony outside his second-story room at theLorraine Motelin Memphis, Tennessee. The civil rights leader was in Memphis to support a sanitation workers‚Äô strike and was on his way to dinner when a bullet struck him in the jaw and severed his spinal cord. King was pronounced dead after his arrival at a Memphis hospital. He was 39 years old.
On April 3, back in Memphis, King gave his last sermon, saying, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got some difficult days ahead. But it really doesn‚Äôt matter with me now, because I‚Äôve been to the mountaintop‚Ä¶ And He‚Äôs allowed me to go up to the mountain. And I‚Äôve looked over, and I‚Äôve seen the Promised Land. I may not get there with you. But I want you to know tonight that we, as a people, will get to the promised land.‚Äù
One day after speaking those words, Dr. King was assassinated by a self-procliamed racist sniper.
Words via www.history.com

On April 3, 1860 the Pony Express mades in cross-country debut with a relay of riders starting off in St. Joseph, Missouri and Sacramento, California‚Äîeach team‚Äôs destination being the other team‚Äôs starting point. The first delivery took a record-breaking ten days. While the idea of the Pont Express is often romanticized and celebrated as a heroic way of life in the West, it was actually a short-lived, unprofitable business that folded one year later, with the advent of the transcontinental telegraph line and after a failed attempt to land a shipping contract with the U.S. government.
Photo courtesy Library of Congress; Man from the Pony Express, on horseback, fleeing from Indians, on Indian burial grounds. Lithograph circo 1860.

Monday after Easter is known as Dyngus Day in Poland and in the Polish-American community. It is a day when males flirt with females by splashing them with water. (The gals get their revenge the next day with similar pranks.) While its origins and specific meaning are not documented, the tradition is known to date back to the 1400‚Äôs and pagan rituals involving water and eggs‚Äîboth symbols of Spring and fertility. In modern times, it is seen as a post-Lenten celebration, similar to Mardi Gras, but on the other end of the 40-day fast. The biggest Dyngus Day celebration in the United States is in Buffalo, NY.

On March 26, 1885 the Eastman Dry Plate and Film Co. of Rochester, N.Y., manufactured the first commercial motion picture film. George Eastman started manufacturing paper film in 1885 before switching to celluloid in 1889. His first camera, which he called the "Kodak," was first offered for sale in 1888. It was a very simple box camera with a fixed-focus lens and single shutter speed, which along with its relatively low price appealed to the average consumer. The Kodak came pre-loaded with enough film for 100 exposures and needed to be sent back to the factory for processing and reloading when the roll was finished. (text courtesy Connor Whelan/slideshare.net)
Photos courtesy Eastman Museum #EastmanKodak #Eastman #Kodak #film #photography #arthistory #photohistory #moviehistory #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #thedailybeast

President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed an executive order authorizing the War Relocation Authority, which was put in charge of interning Japanese-Americans. 110,000 Japanese immigrants and Japanese-Americans on the west coast were forcibly removed from their homes and placed in the interment camps after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Roosevelt calling all Japanese persons a threat to America.
This event struck a personal chord with famous photographer Ansel Adams when his parents' longtime employee in poor health, was summarily picked up by authorities and sent to a hospital halfway across the country in Missouri. Angered by this event, Adams welcomed an opportunity in 1943 to photograph Japanese-American internees at the Manzanar War Relocation Center in California. Adams was anxious for a more meaningful project related to the war effort. Adams's documentation of Manzanar would become his most significant war-related project.
When offering the collection of over 200 photographs to the Library of Congress in 1965, Adams wrote, "The purpose of my work was to show how these people, suffering under a great injustice, and loss of property, businesses and professions, had overcome the sense of defeat and despair by building for themselves a vital community in an arid (but magnificent) environment.‚Äù
Photo ¬©Ansel Adams/Library of Congress In this photo: Richard Kobayashi, cabbage farmer at Manzanar War Relocation Center, CA 1943. #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #AnselAdams #JapaneseHistory #AmericanHistory #internmentcamp #WPA #WWII #thedailybeast

‚ÄúBeware the Ides of March.‚Äù
From our partner @Aboutdotcom:
The Ides of March is a day on the traditional Roman calendar that corresponds to the date of March 15 on our current calendar. It is most commonly associated with the assassination of Julius Caesar. The Ides of March became well-known and notorious as the official date of Julius Caesar‚Äôs assassination in the year 44 BC. Caesar‚Äôs assassination was the result of a conspiracy by a coalition of Roman senators. At the time of his assassination, Caesar was the dictator of the Roman Republic, and the senators feared his power, and that he might overthrow them in favor of general tyranny. He was murdered near the Theatre of Pompey where the Senate was meeting on the Ides of March. Before Caesar went to the theater of Pompey to attend the Senate meeting, he had been given advice not to go, but he did not listen. Caesar‚Äôs assassination transformed Roman history, as it was a central event in marking the transition from the Roman Republic to the Roman Empire. His assassination resulted directly in the Liberator‚Äôs Civil War, which was waged to avenge his death. With Caesar gone, the Roman Republic did not last long, and was eventually replaced by the Roman Empire, which lasted approximately 500 years. The initial two centuries of the Roman Empire‚Äôs existence were known to be a time of supreme and unprecedented stability and prosperity. The time period came to be known as ‚ÄúRoman Peace.‚Äù
Painting: Die Ermordung C√§sars, Karl von Piloty (1865) ¬©istockphoto

March is National Save Your Vision Month, Workplace Eye Wellness Month, and Eye Donor Month. Take a moment to consider your eye health. 80% of sight impairment is preventable or curable. Factors like nutrition, rest, and environmental conditions all affect your eyes' well-being. Here are a few fun facts about the human eye:
‚Ä¢All blue-eyed people can be traced back to one common ancestor from the Black Sea area nearly 100,000 years ago.
‚Ä¢The human eye can see about 10 million colors‚Äîunless you have the genetic mutation that allows you to see a few million more colors (typically affects women), or color blindness (typically affects men).
‚Ä¢Where the human fingerprint has about 40 unique markers, the human eye has over 256‚Äîmaking it a more secure form of bio-identification.
‚Ä¢Night vision goggles are green, because the human eye can differentiate more shades of this color than any other.
‚Ä¢Your eyes remain nearly the same size from birth to death, while nose and ears continue to grow.
‚Ä¢80% of our memories are related to vision.
‚Ä¢The eye is the second-most complex human organ, after the brain, with over 200 million working parts.
‚Ä¢You see with your brain, not your eyes. Our eyes function like a camera, capturing light and sending data back to the brain.
‚Ä¢You blink an average of 10-15 times a minute. You blink more when you walk, protecting them from danger. And you blink less when looking at a computer screen, thus they begin to feel tired.
‚Ä¢Our eyes only ‚Äúread‚Äù three colors‚Äîred, blue, and green‚Äîand everything is upside-down. Our brain interprets all of this information into what we understand as our vision.
#todayinhistory #nationalobservance #eyewellness #humaneye #vision #biology #health #thedailybeast

The iconic Hubble telescope‚Äôs view of the ‚ÄúPillars of Creation.‚Äù The original jaw-dropping photo, taken in 1995, revealed never-before-seen details of three giant columns of cold gas bathed in the scorching ultraviolet light from a cluster of young, massive stars in a small region of the Eagle Nebula, or M16. In 2014, NASA revisited the Pillars, providing astronomers with a sharper and wider view. This time, the area was photographed in near-infrared light, as well as visible light; the infra-red pierces through dense clouds of space dust and gas, giving astronomers a clearer view. This updated study tells us the Pillars of Creations are also a place of destruction. As explained by @NASA: ‚ÄúAt the top edge of the left-hand pillar, a gaseous fragment has been heated up and is flying away from the structure, underscoring the violent nature of star-forming regions. These pillars represent a very dynamic, active process. The gaseous pillars are actually getting ionized, a process by which electrons are stripped off of atoms, and heated up by radiation from the massive stars. And then they are being eroded by the stars‚Äô strong winds and barrage of charged particles, which are literally sandblasting away the tops of these pillars.‚Äù
Photo courtesy NASA/ESA/Hubble Heritage Team (STScI/AURA)/J. Hester, P. Scowen #space #stars #EagleNebula #NASA #astronomy #HubbleTelescope #picoftheday #photooftheday #thedailybeast

March 12, 1930 Gandhi begins his march to the sea to symbolize his defiance of British rule in India. The act of civil disobedience, known as The Salt March, protested British rule in India. It was called The Saly March because British Salt Acts prohibited the collecting or selling of salt, a staple in the Indian diet, forcing native citizens to purchase from the British monopoly over the vital mineral. Gandhi began his 240-mile journey to the sea with the intention of harvesting salt from the sea, as a nonviolent act of rebellion to British rule. Over 60,000 people were arrested during the time of the march for joining in his act of illegal salt trading. The march produced little immediate progress for India, but it did boost Gandhi as a leader of the oppressed, empowering them to stand up for their rights‚Äîa philosophy adopted by Martin Luther King, Jr.

‚ÄúFrankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus‚Äù was first published on March 11, 1818 by English author Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley. Fearful of revealing her identity as the female author of a grotesque, complex human fable, Shelley first published her book anonymously at age 20. Her name was later added to new editions.
‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù is the story of a young science student Victor Frankenstein, who creates a grotesque but sentient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment. His story is framed within the correspondence of North Pole explorer Captain Walton and his sister. Much to the misunderstanding of popular culture today, the monster in the story is actually without a name, reflective of Dr. Frankenstein‚Äôs rejection of his wretched creature.

China's First Emperor, Qin Shihuang, planned to spend his afterlife buried in a palatial tomb, surrounded by all his worldly treasures. To guard his mausoleum, he commissioned an army of terracotta warriors unlike anything seen before or since. Archaeologists estimate that there are about 8,000 terracotta figures in the areas surrounding Qin Shihuang's tomb, including horses, archers, charioteers, infantry, and generals. Most of the terracotta warriors are over six feet tall, substantially larger than the average citizen of the Qin empire at the time. In order to make the the terracotta warriors, it is estimated that more than 1,000 convicts and conscripts were pressed into service, divided into groups, and overseen by the Emperor‚Äôs foremen. As depicted in this model, workers prepared massive amounts of clay for production and built each warrior by hand.
These terra cotta warriors are on display in Chicago now through January 8, 2017 at @FieldMuseum in Chicago, IL Photo ¬©Adam Baker/Flickr #FieldMusem #TerraCottaWarriors #ChineseHistory #museums #worldhistory #ChineseEmperor #QinShihuang #thedailybeast

Meet Piper. This 7 year old Border Collie has a very important job, and he (and his handler Brian Edwards) takes his work very seriously! Piper is one of only a handful of dogs in the U.S. to work ‚Äúground patrol‚Äù at an airport. Employed by Cherry Capital Airport in Traverse City, MI, he detects and chases off wildlife that might get dangerously tangled up with airplanes and helicopters. Seen here in his full work attire, Piper has sun and dust protection for his eyes, special puppy muffs to protect his ears from loud aircraft engines, special shoes for hot asphalt and icy or salted runways, visibility blinkers, a tracker, and an official US Coast Guard harness complete with trauma kit. According to his official website, Piper‚Äôs clocked over 2,640 hours of work time (with plenty of nap breaks), chased away 2,450 birds, and patrolled nearly 600 miles! Astronaut Scott Kelly just returned to Earth after spending a year in Space. While orbiting the Big Blue Marble, Kelly tweeted photos of his journey. Here: A Zinnia plant pillow floats through the U.S. Destiny Laboratory aboard the International Space Station. The zinnias are part of the flowering crop experiment that began on Nov. 16, 2015, when NASA astronaut Kjell Lindgren activated the Veggie system and its rooting "pillows" containing zinnia seeds. The challenging process of growing the zinnias provided an exceptional opportunity for scientists back on Earth to better understand how plants grow in microgravity, and for astronauts to practice doing what they‚Äôll be tasked with on a deep space mission: autonomous gardening.

March commemorates Women‚Äôs History Month. Today we celebrate the contributions and efforts of Jane Addams (1860-1935) whose life work consisted of fighting for the poor and disenfranchised as an activist, social worker, suffragette, and peacemaker. Upon founding Hull House in Chicago, IL, Addams became a role model for social reform, encouraging middle-class women to volunteer, uplift, and educate their communities. The first Hull House was a refuge of innovative social, educational, and artistic programs for immigrants, the poor, and women. The program eventually grew to 500 houses nationwide, and provided a newly formed position of importance for women in leadership roles at Hull Houses. Through her arduous work as a social reformer and speaker, Jane Addams paved the way for many important programs including: child labor regulation, arts enrichment, public sanitation, daycare, health and fitness, gay and lesbian rights, library branch system, juvenile courts, occupational safety, pension laws, multiculturalism, feminism, pacifism, and compulsory education, among other causes. Additionally, Addams was a co-founder of the ACLU. In 1931, she became the first American woman to receive the Nobel Peace Prize.
Photo courtesy Library of Congress @ACLU_nationwide #JaneAddams #HullHouse #WomensHistoryMonth #NobelPeacePrize #socialreform #lgbt #equality #laborlaws #ACLU #civilrights #suffragette #feminist #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory #thedailybeast

In celebrating Black History month, we honor the work of one of the Harlem Renaissance‚Äôs most notable painters, Aaron Douglas. The Harlem Renaissance was the name given to the newly kindled cultural, social, and artistic explosion born in Harlem, New York in the 20‚Äôs and 30‚Äôs. In 1934, he was commissioned, under the sponsorship of the Public Works of Art Project to paint a series of murals for The New York Public Library's 135th Street branch, now the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. Among his best-known works, the four panels of ‚ÄúAspects of Negro Life‚Äù are characteristic of Douglas's style, with graphically incisive motifs and the dynamic incorporation of such influences as African sculpture, jazz music, dance, and abstract geometric forms. Shown here, one of the four panels: ‚ÄúThe Negro in an African Setting.‚Äù Oil on canvas, 1934. The four-panel series is on permanent display at @NYPL‚Äôs #SchomburgCenter Jean Blackwell Hutson Research and Reference Division Reading Room. #HarlemRenaissance #BlackHistoryMonth #ArtHistory #AaronDouglas #SchoburgCenter #NYPL #thedailybeast

American author John Steinbeck was born in Salinas, California on February 27, 1902. Considered a pillar of American literature Steinbeck was inspired by the rich migratory and immigrant experiences of central California. His most famous works are stalpes of high school and college studies, including: Tortilla Flat (1935), Cannery Row (1945), East of Eden (1952), Of Mice and Men (1937), The Red Pony (1937), and Pulitzer Prize-winning The Grapes of Wrath.

On February 24, 1988 the U.S. Supreme Court voted 8-0 on the Hustler Magazine Inc. vs. Jerry Fallwell case, ruling the First Amendment's free-speech guarantee prohibits awarding damages to public figures to compensate for infliction of emotional distress. The ruling reversed Falwell‚Äôs earlier lawsuit awarding him $150,000 against Larry Flynt who orchestrated a parody Campari liquor ad in his Hustler Magazine, in which a Fundamentalist Protestant preacher Falwell recalls his first incestuous sexual encounter with his mother. Because it was obvious (and even stated in print) the Campari ad was satire, the court ruled no person could imply the content to be true or malicious, and struck down the earlier claim of invasion of privacy. After the Supreme Court ruling, the two hot-heads took their arguments on the speaking circuit and became friends!

Today is National Dog Biscuit Day. With so many pet treat recalls lately, why not make your own safe, wholesome snacks for Fluffy and Fido? Here‚Äôs a simple recipe you can try at home. Be sure to know your pooches allergies, make proper bite size, etc. And if you really want to get crazy, eat one yourself at the doggie park. We double dog dare you!
Photo ¬©istockphoto
Ingredients:
2 cups whole wheat flour (you can use another type of flour if your dog is sensitive to wheat or gluten)
1 cup rolled quick oats
1/3 cup smooth, all-natural peanut butter
1 1/4 cups hot water
Feel free to add bits of other ingredients (carrots, cooked meat, etc.) approved by your Veterinarian
Additional flour for rolling
Instructions:
Preheat oven to 350¬∞ F
Mix dry ingredients together.
Mix in the peanut butter and hot water. You may need to add more flour if the dough is too sticky.
Knead the dough well.
Roll out the dough into 1/4" thickness and cut into shapes with cookie cutter or mash down small balls of dough with fork. Optional: egg wash to give baked snacks a sheen.
Bake on a lightly greased cookie sheet for 40 minutes. Turn off the oven and let them cool overnight.
Store in an air tight container, preferably refrigerated, for up to 3 months.

On this day in 1945, the U.S. flag was raised over the Iwo Jima, and the famous photograph ‚ÄúRaising the Flag on Iwo Jima‚Äù was created by Joe Rosenthal. According to @Wikipedia: It depicts five United States Marines and a United States Navy hospital corpsman raising a U.S. flag atop Mount Suribachi, during the Battle of Iwo Jima in World War II. The photograph was extremely popular, being reprinted in thousands of publications. Later, it became the only photograph to win the Pulitzer Prize for Photography in the same year as its publication, and came to be regarded in the United States as one of the most significant and recognizable images of the war, and quite possibly the most reproduced photograph of all time. Three Marines depicted in the photograph, Harlon Block, Franklin Sousley, and Michael Strank, were killed in action over the next few days. The three surviving flag-raisers were Marines Rene Gagnon, Ira Hayes, and Navy hospital corpsman John Bradley.
Photo ¬©Joe Rosenthal/AP/courtesy National Archives #IwoJima #WWII #warhistory #todayinhistory #iconicphoto #blackandwhite #JoeRosenthal #PulitzerPrize #thedailybeast

February honors Black History Month in the US, UK, and Canada. Founded around the birthdates of former slave and abolitionist Frederick Douglas and Abraham Lincoln, who abolished slavery in the US, it is a time to reflect upon the collective history of our culture as a result of the African diaspora. Originally Negro History Week, Kent State students launched Black History Month in 1969, and was adopted by President Ford in 1976. Ford encouraged Americans to ‚Äúseize the opportunity to honor the too-often neglected accomplishments of Black Americans in every area of endeavor throughout our history.‚Äù The celebrations is not without criticism, some believing assigning a month to Black history is a form of segregation. But most use the opportunity to expand awareness of what school books have ignored or erased, allowing our collective, diverse American legacy to continue. 
Photograph: (L) Martin Luther King, Jr. (R) Malcolm X, civil rights leaders of the 1960‚Äôs.
Photo Marion S. Trikosko, U.S. News & World Report Magazine/Courtesy Library of Congress #mlk #malcolmx #civilrights #blackhistorymonth #thedailybeast

Fabien Michenet spends many hours diving at night in deep water off the coast of Tahiti, French Polynesia, where he lives. He is fascinated by the diversity of tiny creatures that migrate up from the depths under cover of darkness. These zooplankton feed on the phytoplankton found near the surface (which need sunlight to photosynthesize) and are themselves hunted by small predators that follow their ascent. One night, about 20 metres (66 feet) below the surface, in water 1,000 metres (3,300 feet) deep, some juvenile octopuses ‚Äì just 2 centimetres (an inch) across, swam into view. ‚ÄòOne of them stopped in front me,‚Äô says Fabien, ‚Äòwaving its tentacles gracefully, perhaps taking advantage of my lights to hunt the little crustaceans that were swimming around.‚Äô Its body was transparent ‚Äì camouflage for the open ocean ‚Äì revealing its internal organs. Chromatophores (colour‚Äëchanging cells) were visible on its tentacles, possibly for use in the light, when a different kind of camouflage would be needed. By keeping as close as possible and drifting at exactly the same speed as the diminutie octopus, and taking care not to upset its natural behaviour with strong lighting, Fabien was able to capture his eye-to-eye portrait.
For more of the Wildlife Photo of the Year winners and runners up, click the link in our profile.

Thomas P Peschak/Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2015
The Shark Surfer
GERMANY/SOUTH AFRICA

Finalist, Photojournalism Award: Single Image

The many sharks to be found at Aliwal Shoal near Durban, South Africa, make it a popular dive site ‚Äì the perfect place to test a prototype surfboard with an electromagnetic shark deterrent. Surfers are occasionally targeted by sharks, but the risk of attack is very low. In 2014, there were 72 unprovoked shark attacks on swimmers worldwide, only 3 fatal. But fear of sharks prevails, and gill nets are still used to kill sharks in the hope of reducing attacks. ‚ÄòI wanted to illustrate a non-lethal approach to mitigating the shark-surfer conflict,‚Äô explains Tom. When the new board was switched off, the curious blacktip sharks swam close, but when it was activated ‚Äì stimulating their sensory organs ‚Äì they stayed at a distance. To avoid bubbles in the picture, Tom free-dived, framing the complementary forms to suggest peaceful coexistence rather than conflict.
For more images, click the link in our profile.

The Labyrinth, New Zealand // As the rain grew heavier, turning the steep slabs around us into the cascades for which Fjordland is famous, my sense of time wandered off. I could only hope it was searching for my sense of direction - which had also been lost for some time now. Shortly after snapping this photo we came to the conclusion that we were standing on the upper ledges of a large cliff band, and that our path back up the way we came was now a waterfall. Cold and wet we reluctantly came to the consensus to bivy, and set about with ice axes, eventually hacking out two small scree ledges under a small overhang (future waterfall). In the early morning, having lost feeling in my legs, Graham‚Äôs shivers roused me from my own purgatory of cold. Together we watched through bleary eyes as the clouds parted long enough to reveal our feet dangling a few meters from 400 ft of open air and a view of the valley below, cascading and wild, from which we were able to orientate ourselves. // @forestwoodward

"We woke this morning in nests of tall tan grass, laid flat by sleeping bag slumberings. Reaching out from where I lay I plucked a small dusty green leaf and rolled it in my fingers, crushing it, the air rich for a moment with the fresh smell of sage. My mind wanders to family road trips through the west as a kid, imagination at the root of it all, then as now. Later, I watched again from a grassy perspective, as Brendan played air traffic controller at the summit of Devils Tower, our laughter deep and free under curious avian wings. Then as now indeed." // @forestwoodward

Elephants Perch, Idaho // Orion cartwheels past, other celestial bodies pause to admire, and with luck, we too rest on edge. // Words and visions from the road and trail with @forestwoodward in this week's guest takeover.

"The first slivers of light creep onto our bodies on the summit push morning. We were frozen and the unknown loomed above us but the sunrise light took me out of the physical suffering for a moment. Halfway through our #runacrosshaiti, we arrived in Gonaives, where I met Santiana. "What do you think of this place?" she asked. Well, I think Haiti is beautiful, and everyone here is very welcoming. "Oh, so you think this is like, Miami beach or something?" The heaps of burning trash were singing my eyes. We passed through villages today where families barely could afford one meal a day. My heart sank as I searched for the words to tell her what I thought about poverty, since it seemed she wanted to know. In my travels, I try my hardest to stretch my understanding. But also not fool myself into thinking I can ever truly know. Santana and I walked along the beach till dark, and shared what we could of our brief time together. That, I hope, is what matters. - @taylorfreesolo

"In October of this past year, I followed and filmed a team of climbers through the jungles of Northern Burma and up to a mountain, Hkakabo Razi. During their summit attempt, I stayed alone at this remote basecamp with a half dozen Burmese porters who didn't speak English. The weeks that followed blew 70mph winds and snow, below freezing temperatures, and we were 200 walking miles from the nearest medical clinic. It was then that I learned --- freaking out does one no good." - @taylorfreesolo

"The Ruth Glacier in the Alaska Range is my favorite Martian landscape. Cerulean supraglacial lakes like these pepper the white ice and silted crevasses. And on this day, I even took a little dip into one of these pools." Taylor Rees (@taylorfreesolo)

It had been over 2 weeks since we had seen the sun. Storm after storm had kept us inside this tiny remote Fjord that had a greater population of sheep than people. 
Finally the clouds parted just enough to give us a shade of sunlight.. It might have been one of the happier days of my life. The winters in Norway can be brutal.

We drove all night... Hit black ice, and almost got our car stuck... But we made it and we scored with no one around. This is why I surf in the arctic!

Photo/caption: @chrisburkard

Freezing water doesn't usually negate a stripping down to your board shorts and jumping in, but we couldn't resist. What was strange was we saw so many tourists with selfie sticks on the shore as we jumped in. It reminded me that nature is really meant to be experienced.. And not just viewed at a distance.
Photo/caption: @ChrisBurkard

I have always been drawn to the landscapes of the North Atlantic. Last fall we stand up paddle boarded up a deep Icelandic canyon named Fjaor√°rglij√∫fur looking for trolls and elves... We didn't find any but we did discover what it must have felt like to live when dinosaurs were around. Photo/caption: @chrisburkard

"It‚Äôs is all a bunch of baloney. Just play music. One thing that‚Äôs never changed is the importance for artists to perform. That is really the heart and soul of it. Going out and performing in front of people, and having them respond to it and talk about it so that you become part of the cultural vocabulary, the cultural landscape. Also, that experience of performing in front of live people informs your art, because there‚Äôs a feedback there. There‚Äôs a response. People clap or they don‚Äôt clap, or they buy tickets, or they don‚Äôt buy tickets. It‚Äôs really basic." - Black Francis of the Pixies on how the band has managed to stay relevant and engage their fans for so long by ignoring the distractions. See the whole interview via the link in our profile. üì∑ @jjamesjoiner

Yvon Chouinard and Doug Tompkins on the first ascent of an un-named peak near the hacabuco area, Patagonia, Chile. I had the honor of climbing a first ascent with two of my biggest heroes. Once on the summit, Doug named the

This is @tommycaldwell working the crux pitch of the Dawn Wall, El Capitan, Yosemite Valley. Tommy and his partner @kjorgeson had spent many seasons working to be the first to free climb this route up the biggest and blankest face of El Captitan. I shot this last December and they completed the climb in a 19-day push a month later. It would become one of the most famous climbs in history because of the unprecedented media frenzy and miss-information. The endeavor is just too difficult to explain to the non-climber in a 30 second sound bite. - @jeffjohnson_beyondandback
#dawnwall

El Capitan, Yosemite Valley. I did a good stint here last December, shooting and climbing. There weren‚Äôt a lot of people around to begin with. Then a storm came in and the Valley was virtually empty. - @jeffjohnson_beyondandback #iphonephoto

Burning man, 2014. My wife and I get invited every year and we always decline. It‚Äôs just not our scene, or so we thought. Last year we went and were blown away. It wasn‚Äôt what we expected. Here‚Äôs a few interesting facts about the event. In it‚Äôs 28-year history there has never been a recorded fight. Not bad with an attendance of over 70-thousand people each year. I can‚Äôt even get five guys drinking beers together without a fight. There is no exchanging money during the event. The only thing that can be bought or sold is ice or coffee from a vendor. 
Everything else is free. There is no corporate branding, no logos. You can‚Äôt even put your name on your art installation. Leave your ego at the door. The Embrace, shown here, took months to build and costs a ton of money. There is no name on it and it gets burnt to the ground on the fifth day of the event. This photo was 
taken with my Leica Monochrom camera and a 50mm lens. - @jeffjohnson_beyondandback #leicamonochrom

It is with heavy hearts that we report author, colleague, and New York Times columnist David Carr has died at 58.

From an internal memo sent by Executive Editor Dean Baquet: "He was the finest media reporter of his generation, a remarkable and funny man who was one of the leaders of our newsroom. He was our biggest champion, and his unending passion for journalism and for truth will be missed by his family at The Times, by his readers around the world, and by people who love journalism."

Africa's #giraffe face a dire future, mainly because of shrinking habitat. 
Their population has fallen 40% in the last 15 years.  Today is the first-ever World Giraffe Day.  Stick your neck out and celebrate Summer Solstice - the longest day day of the year - as well as the world's tallest mammal with the longest neck. A potential customer contemplates a purchase at one of Chiang Mai, #Thailand's expansive night markets. 
Due to the heat, vendors in this northern Thailand city wait until dusk to set up their stalls, when they take over large swaths of the city to sell their wares. 
##These products range rom silk scarves to preserved tarantula spider specimens to everything in between--and often sell for 150-300 Thai baht, or $5-$30 American usd. (Photo by @moneyries)

Adios, Cartagena. Today I'm exiting through the clock tower and heading back to New York. Thanks for following.
Typical street. In the distance is the church of San Pedro Claver, a Spanish-born priest and early abolitionist.
I met this lovely toucan at the ritzy Santa Clara hotel, where Hillary Clinton stayed when she visited Cartagena last year. That's a sculpture by Fernando Botero in the background.
Unfortunately these won't fit in my luggage.
Surprise! A brass band and dancers have shown up in the plaza outside our hotel.
Alert: this building is available to lease! But it's in El Centro, home of the most expensive real estate in Cartagena and probably in all of Colombia.
And the old walled city is in the background here. It's quite small.
Skyline of the newer part of Cartagena, called Bocagrande.

During the Inquisition, this is the window you'd poke your head in to label someone a witch or worse. Then they'd be tortured. It's high enough  off the ground so you don't have to get off your horse. Convenient!
A breakdancer draws a crowd in Plaza de la Aduana. Not bad for a Wednesday night.
Back in Cartagena proper. "Love in the Time of Cholera," which takes place here, features a horse-drawn carriage in an early passage.
More Playa Blanca. It's real nice.

Today we went to Playa Blanca, about 30 minutes from the old city by speedboat. (On a good day, that is. Our boat broke down twice.) We came upon this wheelbarrow of pleasures soon after we landed ashore.
Cartagena after dusk: learning to salsa at a discoteca just outside the walls.

Policarpa Salavarrieta was a spy for the revolutionaries during the Spanish Reconquista. She was killed for treason in 1817. Now she's a Colombian icon and the face of the 10,000 peso. (That's about $5.27.)
More of the old walled city.
The clock tower is the main entrance to the old walled city of Cartagena. Today is overcast.
Hola! This is Beast editor @adamauriemma hijacking the Instagramz for a Cartagena travelogue. I've just arrived in this festive taxi; the driver only took small advantage of my mediocre Spanish.
